ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

TELECOMMUNICATIONS AND INFORMATION TECHNOLOGY INDUSTRY



    1. Mr Chng Hee Kok asked the Minister for Communications and Information Technology whether the Government will adopt a hands-off approach in the development of the telecommunications and information technology industry, especially in the industry's pricing of services and marketing.

    The Minister for Communications and Information Technology (Mr Yeo Cheow Tong): Mr Speaker, Sir, in a fully liberalised and competitive market environment, the Info-communications Development Authority of Singapore, or IDA, will be moving towards regulating with a lighter touch. This will allow more freedom for telecom operators to innovate and compete in terms of pricing and marketing. However, IDA will continue to uphold the key regulatory requirements of fair and equitable inter-connection, inter-operability and open access so that

Column: 814

consumers can transparently and seamlessly communicate with others regardless of whichever network they are directly connected to. Only then will consumers truly benefit from competition in a multi-operator, multi-network environment. IDA also recognises that there will be a transitional phase as we move towards a fully liberalised environment. During this period, it will still be necessary for IDA to keep a vigilant watch over the industry to facilitate the entry of new players.

    Mr Chng Hee Kok (East Coast): Sir, press reports seem to suggest that our telecommunications policies are falling behind Hong Kong and that we are playing catch up. Will the Minister like to comment on that?

    Mr Yeo Cheow Tong: Sir, I am not too sure exactly what Mr Chng is referring to. But if he is referring to the fact that we are now opening up the market fully with effect from 1st April 2000 instead of 2002 whereas Hong Kong has a fully liberalised environment, then it is true. We cannot hide from the fact that we have stipulated a deadline for the opening up of the market and this deadline was stipulated when we first privatised Singapore Telecom and when we invited tenders for the second fixed line network in Singapore which was set in 1996.

Column: 814

SINGAPORE TELECOM AND CABLE & WIRELESS HKT
(Proposed merger)


    2. Mr Chng Hee Kok asked the Minister for Finance if he will explain the rationale for the merger between Singapore Telecom and Cable & Wireless HKT and whether there are any long-term security concerns due to the dilution of Government controls.

    3. Mr Tay Beng Chuan asked the Minister for Finance if he will state the Government's position regarding the proposed merger between Singapore Telecom and Cable & Wireless HKT, and if there are any plans to safeguard our shareholders' interests in the proposed merger in the face of adverse reactions

Column: 815

from certain quarters of the business community in Hong Kong.

    Mr Chng Hee Kok: Sir, before I ask Question No. 2, I wish to declare my interest as an independent director of Pacific Century Development Limited. Question No. 2, Sir.

    The Minister for Finance (Dr Richard Hu Tsu Tau): Mr Speaker, Sir, may I have your permission to take Question Nos 2 and 3 together as they are related?

    Mr Speaker: Yes, you may.

    Dr Richard Hu Tsu Tau: Sir, the proposed merger is driven purely by commercial considerations. The combined entity, which would become one of the leading regional telcos, would be better positioned to face the challenges posed by the rapidly globalising and evolving telecommunications industry.

    The potential dilution of Government's shareholdings in SingTel should not pose security problems. Concerns over security confront telecommunication markets worldwide whenever mergers and acquisitions of telcos, whether foreign or local, take place. However, these security concerns can be adequately addressed through the regulatory framework.

    Temasek Holdings and SingTel believe that the merger will create value for the shareholders of both SingTel and Cable & Wireless HKT. As with all commercial companies, they take into account the interest of its shareholders, including minority shareholders, when making any business decisions, particularly major ones involving mergers and acquisitions.

    The Government does not intend to institute any specific safeguards for shareholders, as the investing public should exercise prudence in their investments. The caveat emptor applies to all investments, including investment using CPF as well as those under Asset Enhancement schemes.

    Mr Chng Hee Kok: Sir, I have two supplementary questions. The first question is, if this is strictly a commercial

Column: 816

deal, press speculation is that it is more than commercial but political as well, especially in our case, one of our Ministers has approached the Hong Kong government on behalf of SingTel.

    The second question is that Government's shareholding in SingTel will continue to be diluted as a result of the loyalty shares issued to current shareholders. Which point will the Minister feel comfortable that we need to improve the framework to make sure that Government still has control over SingTel?

    Dr Richard Hu Tsu Tau: Sir, on the first question, I am in no position to comment on these speculations. These are pure speculations on the part of the media. As far as the Singapore Government is concerned, this is a purely commercial consideration. The fact that Government has a major shareholding is irrelevant in this particular case.

    On the second question, whilst the proposed merger may dilute the Government's shareholding it should not affect the security concerns. This is because the Info-communications Development Authority has already put in place provisions to safeguard national interest. For example, as a licence condition, telecom operators will be required to cooperate fully with relevant Government agencies for the provision of national security and emergency services. We will cover this particular problem through the regulatory requirements.

    Mr Tay Beng Chuan (Nominated Member): Sir, I would like the Minister to clarify. Since the public listing of Singapore Telecom, the share price has fallen below the listed price. I would like to know whether sufficient efforts have been taken by Singapore Telecom and the relevant authorities to restore the confidence of the Singapore shareholders to achieve the original purpose, ie, to enhance the scheme to give Singaporeans a stake in Singapore.

    Mr Speaker: Mr Tay, I do not see the relevance of your question to the Questions which are on the Order Paper.

    Mr Tay Beng Chuan: In the light of the proposed merger, we know that SingTel's share price has fallen below its listed price.

Column: 817



    Dr Richard Hu Tsu Tau: Sir, I think share prices will have to reflect what the market demand is and Government is in no position to influence it directly. I am confident that SingTel management has done all it can to strengthen the position of SingTel but the Member should realise that, all telecom monopolies as SingTel was, are subject to extremely strong competitive pressures as a result of deregulation. The same situation has happened in all countries where share prices of monopolies tend to take a major hit because their overseas IDD calls are usually the ones first hit by competition. As far as SingTel is concerned, they have expanded overseas into many areas, Belgium, UK and Australia, and Members have read in the press that they have made several moves to acquire other telcos, but with mixed success, unfortunately.

    I did not get the second part of the question. Can the Member repeat it?

    Mr Tay Beng Chuan: SingTel was the first of a series of Government enterprises to be privatised and it was part of the Asset Enhancement Scheme. The drop in its share prices will reduce public confidence in this scheme.

    Dr Richard Hu Tsu Tau: In the case of SingTel, the public was granted a discount of the original price and with the loyalty shares the effective price paid by shareholders is a lot lower than $3.60. But I think the basic principle is that Government cannot protect the price of shares. As I mentioned earlier in my reply to Mr Chng's question, investors must make their own judgment and I still believe that, in the long term, SingTel is a good investment.

    Mr Tay Beng Chuan: Sir, since Pacific Century Cyberworks is also bidding for a share of the Cable & Wireless HKT, I would like to know what is the Ministry's position on that.

    Dr Richard Hu Tsu Tau: The Ministry has no position on this. This is an independent bid from a Hong Kong entity and, like all proposals, it is being put on the table in competition with the SingTel deal. I have no comment on this particular case.

Column: 818

INVESTMENTS IN BINTAN AND OTHER RIAU ISLANDS


    The following Question stood in the name of Mr Chiam See Tong -

    4. To ask the Minister for Trade and Industry whether the recent riots in Bintan Island have affected Singapore's investments in that and the other Riau islands and what steps will the Singapore Government take to prevent or lessen the chances of further riots taking place as Singaporeans have their investments there.

    5. Mr Tay Beng Chuan asked the Minister for Trade and Industry what is his Ministry's assessment on the current political and economic situation in Indonesia, and how his Ministry will continue to encourage Singapore businessmen to invest in Indonesia.

    Mr Leong Horn Kee (Bishan-Toa Payoh): Sir, Question No. 4.

    The Minister for Trade and Industry (BG George Yong-Boon Yeo): Mr Speaker, can I have your permission to answer Question Nos 4 and 5 at the same time, please?

    Mr Speaker: Yes.

    BG George Yong-Boon Yeo: Thank you. The political situation in Indonesia has improved since the presidential election in October last year. President Abdurrahman Wahid enjoys domestic political legitimacy and wide international support. The present Indonesian leadership is possibly the best combination under the circumstances.

    However, the present government inherited multi-faceted problems when it assumed power last year. The security situation has not fully stabilised. There are still many social problems. Racial and religious violence continues to break out from time to time. These problems faced by the government are complex and cannot be resolved in a short time. The President is trying to address and resolve the many challenges it now faces.

Column: 819



    As for the Indonesian economy, it is showing a tentative recovery. Real GDP is expected to register a flat or slightly positive growth in 1999, after contracting nearly 14% the previous year. The consensus forecast for GDP growth for Indonesia this year is about 3-5%.

    In January this year, the Prime Minister led an international business delegation to Jakarta as a demonstration of our confidence in Indonesia. PM Goh also announced a package of economic assistance measures to help catalyse Indonesia's economic recovery. For Singapore businessmen, there is the $400 million loan financing scheme administered by the EDB through participating Singapore-based banks. This scheme is to encourage Singapore companies to look for commercially viable opportunities in Indonesia. When these are identified, these companies can seek loan financing at competitive interest rates from the participating Singapore-based banks. The risk of the loans will be shared between the Singapore Government and the participating banks. A seminar was just held on 18th February to elaborate on the details of the scheme. The response was very good.

    Other elements of the assistance package include a US$500 million Singapore Co-Investment Fund for the major Singapore Government-linked companies to support other foreign investors who may be interested in acquiring IBRA-held assets and other financially viable investments. Our Tourism Board will also implement a $2 million Tourism and Marketing Package to help Indonesia restart its tourism promotion activities. At the same time, we will continue to work with the Indonesian authorities to enhance the investment climate in the Riaus.

    By our investments and efforts, we hope to create a positive catalytic effect that will help to attract additional investment funds from other foreign investors. However, ultimately, whether the businessmen will decide to invest in Indonesia depends on their assessment of the prospects. They will choose to invest in places where they and their investments are safe and their

Column: 820

operations can carry on uninterrupted. They will be monitoring if the current Indonesian leadership pursues sound economic policies and if there is political and social stability within Indonesia.

    In this regard, it is unfortunate that the issue of land compensation at the Bintan Industrial Estate has resurfaced. When development works by the Indonesia-Singapore joint venture company on the Bintan Industrial Estate began more than five years ago, compensation for the land was fully settled and the land was free of encumbrances.

    The recent demonstrations at the Bintan Industrial Estate have resulted in losses for the companies operating there as work had to be stopped. They have also affected tourist arrivals, and undoubtedly, the livelihood of the people in Bintan as well. The disturbances, if unchecked, would not only affect investors in the Estate, but more seriously, it would dampen foreign investor confidence in Indonesia. Singapore's ability to act as a catalyst to enhance investor confidence in Indonesia and help bring back foreign investment there would be curtailed.

    The Singapore Government has conveyed to the Indonesian authorities, at various levels, the importance for Indonesia to resolve the problems. However, the disturbances in Bintan should be seen in the context of the other incidents of social unrest elsewhere in Indonesia. President Wahid himself has said that the recent outbreaks of unrest in Indonesia were the product of a conspiracy against his government. The Indonesian authorities have indicated that disruptive elements from other parts of Indonesia had been involved in Bintan. They recognise the nature and potential impact of the problems and have taken swift action to end the disturbances. We will continue to closely monitor the situation in Bintan.

    Mr Chiam See Tong (Potong Pasir): Sir, I have three supplementary questions. Firstly, has the land compensation issue been resolved there? Secondly, what is the population of Bintan and what percentage of the population has been

Column: 821

given jobs by the investments there? Thirdly, has the Singapore Government or its linked companies helped or assisted the private investors to provide social needs such as medical clinics and schools for the population there?

    BG George Yong-Boon Yeo: Mr Speaker, Sir, as far as we are concerned, the issue of land compensation was settled when the land was acquired before the industrial estate was established. The land, as I had said earlier, was free of encumbrances. Whether the money in fact went to the people from whom the land was taken, that is something for the Indonesian side to resolve, and I believe that they are taking actions in that direction. But as I also mentioned earlier, Jakarta suspects that there were political elements involved in the disturbances.

    As to the population of Bintan, I do not have it with me now.

    Mr Chng Hee Kok: It is 600,000.

    BG George Yong-Boon Yeo: 600,000 according to Mr Chng Hee Kok. We provide employment in the Bintan Industrial Estate and in the tourism area for some thousands, maybe at the most ten plus thousands. Do we provide facilities there? Where we are located, we do provide some facilities to the workers and to the surrounding areas.

    Mr Tay Beng Chuan: In respect of the $40 million regionalisation finance scheme for Indonesia, the rules are quite rigid and I would like to know whether they can be relaxed somewhat to include the purchase of existing Indonesian under-capacity companies so that the Singapore businessmen do not need to use new funds to build a new factory or to purchase new equipment because there are quite a lot of under-capacity companies. I would like to ask the Minister whether this could be considered in this scheme.

    BG George Yong-Boon Yeo: Mr Speaker, Sir, we had a seminar with many Singapore businessmen last week. It was so heavily subscribed that we had to

Column: 822

reduce the number of executives which each company was allowed to send for the seminar. Comments had been made. Their feedback is now being analysed and we will liberalise the rules as much as we can, but without losing sight of prudential considerations. We must be aware of the unstructured investment environment in Indonesia, the difficulty of enforcing contracts, and we must not forget that public monies are involved here. But where we can be liberal, we shall try to be.

Column: 822

RESTRUCTURING STATUS OF POWER INDUSTRY


    6. Mrs Lim Hwee Hua asked the Minister for Trade and Industry if he will give an update on the status of the restructuring of the local power industry, particularly with regard to the introduction of competition to both electricity generation and supply, and whether there is any intention to limit the number of players in each segment.

    BG George Yong-Boon Yeo: Mr Speaker, Sir, since 1995, the Government had taken several steps to restructure the electricity industry, starting with the corporatisation of the Electricity and Gas Departments of the Public Utilities Board (PUB) to form Singapore Power Ltd (SP) on 1st October 1995. To facilitate competition, Singapore Power was structured as a holding company with five separate subsidiaries, namely two generation companies (PowerSenoko and PowerSeraya), a transmission & distribution company (PowerGrid), a supply company (Power Supply) and a piped-gas company (PowerGas).

    Another power station being built in Tuas was put under a separate company, Tuas Power Ltd (TP), owned directly by Temasek Holdings, so that it could compete against the SP generation companies. To facilitate competition in the generation and supply sectors, the Singapore Electricity Pool (SEP) was established as an exchange for trading electricity.

    The Government decided in March 1999 that the next step in restructuring the electricity industry was for Singapore Power to fully divest its generating

Column: 823

companies to Temasek Holdings in 2001. This will bring about ownership separation of the generators, which are the contestable part of the market, from the transmission and distribution network, which is the non-contestable part. All generators will have a level playing field. The transmission and distribution network will be regulated tightly as a natural monopoly. In the year 2001, there will be four competing generation companies, PowerSenoko, PowerSeraya, Tuas Power and SembCorp Co-gen.

Review of Industry Structure

    Many more countries have now liberalised their electricity services. As a result, electricity prices have dropped significantly. Consumers have benefited with greater choice, better product innovation and better service quality.

    To ensure the competitiveness of our electricity sector, MTI will further liberalise the electricity market with the aim to put in place a fully competitive market. We have engaged a consultant to carry out a comprehensive review of the electricity industry and to recommend how competition in the sector could be further enhanced. The consultant has just completed its review and we are now evaluating the changes recommended by the consultant. We will announce the changes once we have obtained feedback from industry players.

Number of players

    There is currently no limit on the number of players in the generation and retail sectors of the electricity industry. Companies that want to generate or supply electricity in Singapore can apply to the PUB, the Regulator, for a public licence. The PUB will evaluate the application to ensure that the proposed project complies with our technical requirements, rules and regulations to safeguard system security and that the applicant has the financial capability and technical expertise. A public licence will be granted if these requirements are met. There is no plan to impose any limit on the number of

Column: 824

players in the future. With the liberalisation of our electricity market, the number of players in the generation and supply segments will be determined by market forces.

    Mrs Lim Hwee Hua (Marine Parade): Sir, notwithstanding the experience of the other markets of falling prices, is there a philosophy that we would adopt with respect to pricing which will serve to preserve the interest of domestic consumers as well as from the perspective of the overall cost competitiveness of Singapore?

    BG George Yong-Boon Yeo: Our intention is, within the next two years, to move towards as free a market as is possible and adopt an ideal framework with marginal pricing. We believe that the interests of consumers are best met by allowing market forces to put pressure on the generators to reduce prices.

    Mr Simon S. C. Tay (Nominated Member): Sir, can I ask whether, in the review of the market, will the study include the desire for greater efficiency in order to curb excessive use of power and to encourage greater efficiency in the use by industry as well as households?

    BG George Yong-Boon Yeo: I do not think we should put ourselves in the position of deciding who has a greater need for power. From our perspective, the best way is to use the market mechanism to decide who has a greater need for power according to what he is prepared to pay. In other words, to let the market mechanism operate rather than to impose additional considerations as to who should get power at what prices, depending on whether they undertake activities which are socially worthy.

    Mr Simon Tay: Perhaps I was misunderstood. What I mean is that Singapore has one of the highest climate-change gases already and that in creating a market for energy generation, we run the danger of creating a market where you use more power, you get more profits. I am wondering whether these dangers will overall affect Singapore's standing in such

Column: 825

community as well as our efficiency. Would these factors be taken into consideration in creating this market for competition?

    BG George Yong-Boon Yeo: I am sorry. I did not quite catch what you said earlier.

    Mr Simon Tay: May I clarify myself? In the generation of power, there would be release of climate-change gases and other pollutants which would affect both the global climate as well as our local environment.

    BG George Yong-Boon Yeo: You are referring to greenhouse gases?

    Mr Simon Tay: Yes, greenhouse gases.

    BG George Yong-Boon Yeo: We observe all international regulations on this and whatever we do, we will conform to international standards and we will play our part as part of our international responsibility but within those constraints, let the market operate.

    Mr Chng Hee Kok: I wish to declare my interest as a director of Singapore Power. My question to the Minister is: will he allow Genco's to supply power to the Grid from outside Singapore, for example, Malaysian independent power supplier?

    BG George Yong-Boon Yeo: I think we should allow the importation of power on a selective basis by taking into account the needs of energy security in Singapore. We are already connected to the Malaysian Grid, but not as if we were part of the same grid, but in an emergency, we supply to them, they can supply to us. We should be able to do the same with Indonesia too one day, depending on the economics. But at all times, we must take into account the fact that energy security is our own responsibility which we must safeguard.

    Mr Chng Hee Kok: If we free up the market completely, it is going to be hard to be selective about who should supply and how much to supply, is it not?

Column: 826



    BG George Yong-Boon Yeo: Cross-boundary electricity flows are completely within our powers to regulate and control. Is that your question? I am not sure.

    Mr Chng Hee Kok: No. My question really is that if they are prepared to supply power at a much lower price, how do you determine that the Singapore consumers should not benefit and at the same time keeping in mind the long-term interest of Singapore?

    BG George Yong-Boon Yeo: We will take these factors into account. If power is available very cheaply from Malaysia and the quality of that supply can be assured, then we should surely in our own interest consider it.

    Dr S. Vasoo (Tanjong Pagar): Sir, can I ask the Minister whether a watchdog body, which comprises consumers and operators, could be set up to ensure that consumers are protected, like in Hong Kong where they have a watchdog body?

    BG George Yong-Boon Yeo: The agency having principal responsibility for this would be the Public Utilities Board.

STANDARD OF MEDICAL AND HEALTHCARE PRACTICES

    Mr Speaker, Sir, I explained in Parliament in March last year the rationale for the formation of the statutory board, which I would like to reiterate this afternoon.

Approach of the SMU Bill

    To provide SMU with the flexibility and autonomy to innovate and break new ground, SMU will be structured in a different way from NUS and NTU. While NUS and NTU are statutory boards each governed by an Act of Parliament, SMU will be structured as a private company limited by guarantee. There will be a two-tier approach. SMU's daily operations are governed by the Memorandum and Articles of Association (M&A) of the company which was incorporated on 12th January this year. The company called The Singapore Management University is also subject to the provisions of the Companies Act.     The SMU Bill aims to serve four key functions:

    First, it gives SMU the right to confer and award degrees, diplomas and certificates, including honorary degrees and other distinctions;

    Second, the Bill allows for Government funding to be provided to the institution. This will help ensure that SMU develops successfully, especially in the start-up phase, and signals to the public governmental support for SMU;

    Third, it permits the Government, when necessary, to influence the strategic development of SMU; and

    Fourth, the Bill permits the Government to monitor the use of public funds.

    Clause 3 sets out the function of the university company, which includes the conferring and awarding of degrees, diplomas and certificates;

    In 1998, I asked my Minister of State to chair an Inter-Ministry Committee to examine the feasibility of introducing Community-Based Sentences into our criminal justice system. Among its recommendations are the extension of the use of Probation to adult offenders, and the introduction of Tail-End Home Detention, Boot Camp, Community Service Orders and Re-integrative Shaming.

    My Ministry is mindful that the use of Community-Based Sentences must neither compromise the objectives of our penal regime, nor give the victim or the public the impression that our system is becoming lenient towards perpetrators of crimes. Tough penalties would continue to be meted out to deserving offenders. Community-Based Sentences complement, not replace, the traditional forms of punishment of imprisonment, caning and fines.

This is especially so if there are mitigating circumstances. That is why we are amending the Prisons Act to provide for the Tail-End Home Detention Scheme.

Tail-End Home Detention for Penal Inmates

    Tail-End Home Detention is not new. Home Detention has been implemented at the tail-end of the detention period for drug inmates and Criminal Law Detainees as well as Reformative trainees released onto statutory supervision. Countries like the United Kingdom, Sweden and Australia have successfully implemented Home Detention. It serves as an avenue for the earlier release of prisoners who are most amenable to rehabilitation. Its implementation serves a number of purposes.

    Firstly, allowing the offender to be closer to his family and the community will help him to better reintegrate into

Column: 894

society after incarceration. The deterrent element is still retained as offenders will be subjected to restrictions and surveillance via electronic tagging. Secondly, as this scheme allows offenders to remain in the community, it keeps the families intact and allows offenders to be gainfully employed. Reaction to our announcement of the Scheme, especially those from families of offenders, has been positive.

    Clause 10 of the Bill introduces a new Part IVA in the Prisons Act to provide for the Tail-end Home Detention Scheme. The Scheme will allow selected offenders serving jail terms of six months and above to be released early on home detention up to a maximum of six months. These offenders must have served at least half of their imprisonment term before they become eligible.

    The selection of eligible inmates will be based on a stringent set of criteria. Only offenders who are assessed to be least likely to pose a risk to society will be considered for the Scheme. Prisoners serving life imprisonment, offenders of serious or violent crimes, and drug and sexual offenders will not be eligible. Clause 24 of the Bill provides for a new Schedule which lists the type of ineligible offenders. In addition, eligible offenders will go through rigorous assessments to determine their suitability for emplacement onto the Scheme. These assessments will be conducted by the internal Prison committees as well as an independent Advisory Committee, made up of distinguished members of the community. The conduct, attitude and response to rehabilitation and the risk factors of eligible offenders will be scrutinised.

Column: 903

which remains unanswered in the Bill. I would like to ask the Minister whether the cost of the HDS Scheme is lesser or greater in relation to keeping the prisoner in prison at the moment. who is hurt or who suffers economic loss may be looking towards the Ministry for compensation.

Column: 906

flexible enough to ensure that we provide various alternatives in rehabilitating our crime offenders in Singapore.

    Mdm Claire Chiang See Ngoh (Nominated Member): Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker for the opportunity to speak. I would like to raise one main concern on the Bill under the section on home detention order in Part IVA.

Column: 907

is only meaningful if the baseline has first been established on the cognitive and emotive orientations of the prisoner when he first arrived so that the final assessment before the release could measure the changes in him during incarceration.     Could the Minister clarify the meaning in new section 7B that every member of a Committee of Inquiry appointed shall be deemed to be a public servant within the meaning of the Penal Code?     Mr Noris Ong Chin Guan: Sir, I rise to speak in support of this Bill.

    Dangerous and violent criminals deserve to be incarcerated for long periods of time. But for less serious offenders, I see the merit in applying correctional treatment to re-integrate them into the community. I see the social value in having a home detention scheme to minimise the negative socialisation that occurs in prison. It is assuring to know offenders placed on Electronic Monitoring (EM) schemes in other countries register lower recidivism rates. But the success rate varies, and the EM may be more effective with some groups of offenders and at certain stages of the rehabilitation process. A group of American researchers found that EM works better with offenders who have had a taste of prison detention. Apparently, juveniles seem to respond better to EM than adults. EM also seems to be more effective among targeted groups of non-violent offenders, such as drunk drivers.

    In the light of such findings, there is merit in insisting that home detainees should be non-violent offenders and have spent at least six months in prison. Justice is upheld as they have at least been minimally punished in prison. Thereafter, they should not be mixed too often and too long with hardcore criminals. If it is bad company that led some misguided offenders into prison, why test the penitent's resolve by confining him further with proven bad company? Why suffer him to be corrupted even further while in

Column: 909

prison? It is in the public interest to give deserving contrite hearts a second chance. We should grant them the opportunity to redeem themselves so long as they do not pose a risk to the public. It is a fact I wholeheartedly applaud the spirit of the Bill. Nonetheless, I would like to raise several points for the Minister's clarification.

    Firstly, can the Minister clarify the types of inmates who can qualify and benefit most from the scheme? It is in the public interest that the selection guidelines rule that violent and dangerous criminals, murderers, rapists and other inmates convicted of serious crimes should be automatically disqualified from the scheme. They deserve the full prison sentence. There should be no exception to this. But what are the other criteria - family support, good prison behaviour, age? Will these criteria be transparent to the inmates? Are there studies to indicate that certain targeted groups of offenders will benefit most from the scheme?

    Sir, I believe that the home detention scheme can help to steer misguided offenders back to the right path. But what numbers are we referring to here? This leads me to the second point of clarification. Can the Minister provide us with an estimate on the percentage of prisoners who potentially qualify for the home detention scheme? How many detainees, fitted with the EM device, can the community expect at any one time? Does this number affect the Government's plan on the number of prisons to be built in the future?

    Thirdly, what will the detainees do at home? The scheme provides the offenders with a measure of freedom. My concern is that when they are taken off the discipline of regular physical exercise, prison chores and solitude, what are they going to do with their free time at home? We cannot legislate to deny a home detainee the pleasures of his home for what is there to prevent an affluent detainee from enjoying movie after movie on an ultra modern high-tech big screen

Column: 910

home entertainment system together with his family, or hours and hours of Internet surfing, or a nice sun tan after a leisure swim in his private pool, or a home party on Saturday night with his and his family friends.

    Sir, I am not exaggerating. Some years back, a son of a former Amercian Vice-President candidate was sentenced to four months of house arrest for selling cocaine. The home detention was as good as an extended resort holiday. He lived in a luxury apartment, with maid service, cable TV and many other expensive amenities. This led his prosecutor to observe that the drug felon was living in conditions that 99.9% of the people in the area could not afford. Too much free time can be bad for the less affluent detainees too. A home detainee cannot roam the streets. But in the confines of his small HDB flat, he is exposed to the temptations of the streets through his friends, family media. Some of these influences and friends may not be good for him. They may numb him to forget that he is still serving his sentence, albeit at home. While there are devices to ensure that he does not leave his home, we cannot legislate against such influences from entering his home.

    Sir, a new freedom can be a dangerous thing. When we feed idle minds with bad influences, they will breed crooked schemes. Restricted freedom strengthens the resolve for some, but for others, it propagates jealously, resentment and bitterness. To put it simply, home detainees should not be left to their own schemes. Thus, detaining offenders at home is only part of the rehabilitated solution. The other part involves providing structured programmes to occupy their daily routine. Meaningful activities should be included, such as skill upgrading to help the detainees to find suitable jobs later on. Perhaps, the activities also can benefit the community so that there will be a pay back redemptive effect.

    My third point of clarification to the Minister then is how much free time do home detainees have. What kind of rehabilitative programmes would there be?

Column: 911

This leads to my fourth point regarding community service programmes. Community service programmes can supplement the home detention scheme and acts as an additional intermediate sanction. Any minor offender, not necessarily just home detainees, can be put on community service programmes. For example, minor offenders can be made to help out in places like nursing homes or centres for the disabled. They can be assigned simple tasks that require some degree of contact with the elderly or disabled. Minor offenders may find it to be extremely therapeutic when they are exposed to the pride, strength and character of the elderly and disabled. It may even help to change their value system for the better. But such a programme must be managed properly and discreetly.

    In some countries, as part of their sentence, certain offenders have to conduct talks in schools or advise troubled teens. Some convicted sports personalities conduct sports clinics followed by counselling sessions for juveniles. Along this line, is it not better for a convicted computer hacker to help non-profit organisations to create websites, design software programmes, conduct basic IT training rather than for him to rot in prison for the entire period of his sentence?

    Sir, if there is a corrective work order for litterbugs, why cannot there be a corrective social work order for social bugs? Not all social bugs are social menaces. Social menaces should be put away from arm's reach. Some minor social bugs can perhaps be disinfected of their ills by a dosage of corrective social work order. In this light, may I ask the Minister whether he will consider broadening correctional sanctions further to allow minor offenders to perform community services?

    Fifthly, should the home detention scheme always take place at home? The home environment is not necessarily the best rehabilitation centre. Some offenders are in prison precisely because of the lack of guidance at home. The lack of parental support has driven some to bad company and subsequently to prison. If the root of

Column: 912

the problem is at home, why send them back to their homes? In such cases, putting them back to their homes is likely to be counter productive. But does this mean that the offenders must have a supportive home environment in order to qualify for the scheme? I hope not. If penitent offenders do not have a favourable home environment to return to, perhaps they can be detained in some established half-way houses instead.

    It is no secret that some of these half-way houses are founded by ex-convicts. They know what it takes to turn over a new leaf and want to help others to do so. The environment in these half-way houses can be more rehabilitative than the home environment. The sharing of positive experiences, bonding and encouragement can do these detainees a world of good. But there must be a review of the programmes, funding level and management practices of half-way houses. This is because the performance standards, services and facilities of half-way houses may vary too significantly. A benchmarking of the standards of half-way houses is important in this regard. Some degree of recognition and support for half-way houses is also in order. For my fifth point of clarification, may I ask the Minister whether an extension of the home detention scheme to relevant half-way houses has been considered?

    Finally, I turn to the family home detainees who are generally supportive. The family is one of the critical success factors for the scheme. It may not be so in the West because, given their cultural practices, it is conceivable that many home detainees there do not live with their families. But this is generally not the case here. Home detention here can literally mean being detained with the family. A family may seem to be supportive, but we have to recognise that it is one thing to express support and another to be able to deal with the difficulties and shame of living with a detainee. The family has to learn to adjust and accept the concomitant stigma, but not all family members can manage that successfully. The mother may accept but

Column: 913

the father may resent. The sister may bear with it but the brother may find it embarrassing and disgraceful to stay at home with the detainee. And when a family dispute erupts, the detainee cannot run off to cool himself down.

    Not all neighbours can accept living near a detainee either. It is possible for the family to conjure up excuses to explain to their neighbours and relatives regarding the absence of the prisoner from home. But having the detainee locked up at home is altogether a very different thing. Hopefully, the spot checks on home detainees will not be conducted by uniformed law enforcers. Otherwise, the whole neighbourhood will soon know about it. When tongues are set wagging, some home detainees and their family members will fail to deal with the stigma. When this happens, the scheme will backfire and become dysfunctional. Instead of being reintegrated, the scheme may end up disintegrating the whole family. In this regard, may I ask the Minister whether any steps will be taken to minimise the stigma of home detention and to help home detainees and their family members to be prepared for the social and psychological stigma associated with the scheme?

    Mr Chew Heng Ching (East Coast): Sir, I support the Bill and would like to raise a matter of concern that has arisen over the years in my dialogues with residents, and this relates to employment opportunities for ex-prisoners and ex-inmates of rehabilitation centres.

This is an admirable stand and has served us well in making Singapore a country safe for visitors and residents. However, there is a segment of our population, albeit a small one, who had previously served some time in prison or in various rehabilitation centres for errors made in their youth who require help. And there is also quite a high incidence of repeat offenders who have not been granted the opportunities of reintegration into society at large. We have

Column: 914

schemes in prison and rehabilitation centres and now homes to equip some of these individuals with skills and values so that they adjust back to society. However, it is often difficult for such individuals to find gainful employment once they are tarnished with a criminal record. We run the risk of developing by default an underclass who is not given a second chance.

    Sir, our Singapore society is not a very forgiving one. We are very tough on failure, whether it is financial failure in the form of bankruptcy or social failure in the form of poor judgment and influence resulting in criminal activities. Ex-prisoners and ex-inmates of rehabilitation centres are often labelled and are not given opportunities that normal individuals have despite having served out their punishment.     Sir, I feel that we, as Singaporean employers and Government, are not doing enough to give these individuals a chance to assimilate back into society and become responsible citizens who have the ability to fully contribute to our nation's progress. afresh. Also, I would like to urge the Minister to ask our Government agencies, in particular, the airport and the seaport police authorities, to review their policy to allow ex-prisoners and ex-inmates of rehabilitation centres to work in their premises, with the thrust of Singapore 21 in mind as we move towards becoming a more gracious, compassionate and forgiving society.

    Mr Gerard Ee: Sir, I rise to support the Bill.

    It is a positive move to introduce home detention. Whilst it is new to Singapore, it is not new to other countries. It is a tested system and it can work well in the Singapore environment. to open it to the public, would the Minister decide? Certainly, I will so decide if there is a public interest to do so. So I see no particular reason why we should favour one term over another when that particular term is easily understood by the rehabilitative or prison authorities in other countries.

    Both Mr Ravindran and Prof. Chin asked whether this home detention scheme is more rehabilitative or perhaps merely a measure to reduce over-crowding in prisons. We know, of course, that there is an over-crowding situation in the prisons, but that is because many of our prisons' capacities are designed based on the old norms and we do not have many new prisons lately. Column: 918

arose from a study that I have asked my Minister of State to make together with other interested parties on what are the other alternative sentencing options that could be made available in our criminal justice system. In the process of making its

Column: 919

recommendations, the Committee can call up the inmates and ask questions and review their records. That power is given to the Advisory Committee. In the end, a decision has to be made and that will be made by the Director of Prisons.

    Mr Ravindran asked specifically whether the overcrowding in our prison is the result of the strict sentencing guidelines that have been imposed for offences. There are a number of reasons which I have explained earlier. We always look at the sentencing regime to see whether they are adequate or not. Of course, if they are not, we will review them. On whether we could release prisoners in the process earlier instead of just having the standard remission period, I think the remission of one-third of the prisoner's sentence is already quite generous. Now we are providing the balance of up to six months for the person to serve his sentence at home and I think for a start we should just go for that and not do anything more.

    The prisoners need not pay for the cost of the electronic tagging and the cost of monitoring because this will be borne by the prison authorities. Home detention with electronic tagging is not a new thing that the prison has implemented. As I have said, it has been implemented for criminal law detainees, reformative trainees as well as those detained under the Misuse of Drugs Act. So Prisons Department already has enough experience in dealing with such people, including the process of examining, assessing and investigating whether a person is suitable for home detention or not. That process will be quite exhaustive, including talking to professionals and counsellors if necessary, and, in particular, for home detention, family support is very important. Without family support, there is no purpose in releasing that inmate back to society because we need the family to also play its role in rehabilitating the inmate. Getting the half-way house to do the job is not good enough because we should not just pass the responsibility to the half-way house. But we can get the half-way house to help. For example, in counselling, we can get SANA, VWOs, the

Singapore Aftercare Association to help in the counselling. Counselling would indeed be one of the conditions that the prison would impose on anybody who is on home detention. LIBERALISATION OF THE SINGAPORE STOCK EXCHANGE

5.34 pm

    Dr Wang Kai Yuen: Mr Deputy Speaker, Sir, the long title of my motion is "Issues related to the liberalisation of the Singapore Stock Exchange in the midst of the boom of Internet Stocks". I would like to declare my interest as Director of several listed companies, including I-one.net.

    Until the departure of Mr Koh Beng Seng from the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS), the Singapore Stock Exchange used to be a bastion of conservatism. After the Pan-Electric episode, the SES had adopted a regulatory mindset and attempted to protect both the gullible investors and the reckless speculators in essentially a buyer-beware market. From time to time, rules for listed companies were made even more stringent with new requirements such as the requirement of an independent Audit Committee and full disclosure of directors' fees.

    Listing requirements of Initial Public Offering (IPO) were very stringent, especially those seeking to list on the main board. These companies must have proven track records of profitability.

    As a result, the SES became a comparatively calm equity market where speculations were minimal. It acquired a reputation of being a safe market, in so far as an equity market could be made safe. The collective memory of the public is that SES is a strict taskmaster. When a company obtained the approval from the SES to list, the public assumed that someone had done the due diligence and the company's fundamentals had been certified sound.

    This public image has remained unchanged today, even though in the

Column: 926

post-Koh Beng Seng era, the SES, recently renamed SGX, has modified its stance, moving away from its regulatory role and becoming more a stock exchange like the New York Stock Exchange. Companies seeking IPO no longer need a track record of proven profitability. In fact, MediaRing, when it was being listed, had projected to continue its multi-million dollar losses for the next few years! In essence, any company with a market capitalisation of more than S$80 million post-IPO and could find a merchant banker prepared to underwrite the IPO exercise, could tap the market for funds.

    In principle, I believe, Mr Deputy Speaker, Sir, these relaxations are appropriate if SGX were to remain viable and relevant in an increasingly dynamic equity market. Otherwise, more and more market players will bypass SGX and invest in other stock markets in the world, an undertaking made easier because of Internet trading. Unfortunately, as the liberalisation has been quite recent, the fact that SGX is now a less regulated market and hence a more risky place has not yet dawned in the collective memory of the public.

    Concurrently, in the liberalisation process, a new kind of companies has burst onto the scene worldwide: the Internet companies. High-tech companies and Internet companies have been the darlings of the US capital market for several years now. Companies, which lose money consistently, continue to see their share prices appreciate. Traditional indicators of company's performance no longer seem to be relevant. For instance, the P/E ratio has become meaningless or non-applicable. The famous example is Amazon.com. This fever has spread to other major stock markets in the world. In Japan, Softbank and Hikari become investment companies with the Midas' touch. With the success of China.com and Pacific Internet in the NASDAQ market, the Internet fever has spread to Hong Kong Stock Exchange, SGX, KL Stock Exchange, and even the Bombay Stock Exchange. In Hong Kong, Pacific Century

Column: 927

Cyberworks almost single-handedly leads the charge into the brave new world.

    Sir, in Singapore, taking advantage of the relaxed listing requirements, three dot.com companies were listed one after another since June last year, namely, I-One.net, MediaRing and Horizon.com. All these three IPOs were spectacularly successful with prices peaked at multiple times of the issue prices. The scramble is on. Let me quote from Hock Lock Siew column of 19th February issue of the Business Times:

    "There is big money to be made from the Internet craze in Singapore. The window of opportunity could be closing as more and more Internet firms get listed. Time is of essence. The faster to market, the higher an Internet startup's valuation." There are indeed many dot.com companies in the pipeline vying to go IPO. Gotcha, Nececity, iProperty, GeoAsia, just to name a few. Many companies, in fact, with very little to do with Internet are now frantically transforming themselves into dot.com companies.

    Of course, we are not alone in this. The scene in Hong Kong is even scarier as traditional brick and mortar companies scramble to join the bandwagon. Mr Li Ka-Shing has just launched his Tom.com hoping to raise HK$762 million. I am quite sure many of those dealmakers do not really know the difference between "bytes" and "bites".

    As the valuations of dot.com companies in the US continue to escalate, the dot.com phenomenon is beginning to look like an asset bubble. The Internet sector in the US has a valuation of around US$550 billion or 4% of the total market capitalisation. As an indication of the lofty height NASDAQ has reached, it is pertinent to note that Microsoft alone has a market capitalisation of around US$600 billion, a figure larger than the GDP of Canada! The danger of this asset bubble is that all the stock markets in the world are now pegged to the fortune of NASDAQ. It also means that if NASDAQ crashes, this would bring about a simultaneous crash worldwide. The scenario is indeed very scary. In recent days, while Dow Jones has been declining, the NASDAQ has

Column: 928

continued to power ahead moving in the opposite direction. Despite all the talk of the new economy, nothing can defy the law of gravity ultimately. What goes up must come down.

    Yes, we shall embrace the new economy. Senior Minister in his Chinese New Year's speech at the Tanjong Pagar Community Club urged that young men and women in Singapore with bright ideas should be encouraged to take risks to ensure that their ideas could be brought to fruition. The investing public must be encouraged to give their support to the risk-takers so that a new entrepreneurial group could be produced that would give Singapore's economy that extra zip.

    The question, Sir, is how Singaporeans can participate in the Internet boom without being sucked into the asset bubble. Had our market been known for its high-risk investment environment where investors go into the market with their eyes open, I would be less inclined to be alarmed. As it is, most people still believe that so long as SGX approves an IPO, the company would have been vetted by one of the toughest regulators in the world. As such, sometimes I feel great unease standing by as the speculative fever sucks in the wise and the worldly as well as the greedy but ignorant. I am sure that in our environment, if things ultimately go wrong, our Government will be blamed. And scenes of the Taiwanese speculators petitioning the Government for assistance to recover their lost fortunes flash in my mind.

    Moreover, should the current Internet boom burst, and burst it seems to be sooner or later, would the investors be turned off by all dot.com companies, including those deserving ones, thereby depriving the young and the promising entrepreneurs the lifeline for success? My own preference is for the Government to express stronger words of caution regarding new IPOs of dot.com companies. Perhaps we can follow the practice of cigarette companies printing words like "Smoking is hazardous to your health." But in this case, maybe words like "Profit stream of the company is uncertain. Invest

Column: 929

at your own risk." On the other hand, on a more realistic note, I would prefer to see that companies with unproven track records, such as dot.com companies, be confined to SESDAQ, our secondary market, rather than be listed on the main exchange.

    Even though this is an unenviable and difficult task, I would like to urge the Minister to strike a balance between liberalisation of our stock exchange and the protection of our retail investors, especially in view of the bull run of high-tech and Internet stocks.

    The Deputy Prime Minister (BG Lee Hsien Loong): Mr Deputy Speaker, Sir, I thank Dr Wang Kai Yuen for his intervention. It is a timely reminder of the risks of investing in the stock market.

    Over the last two years, we have liberalised and modernised our capital markets. We have changed the listing rules on SGX to allow a wider range of companies to be listed, including start-up companies with short but strong profit records, and companies which have not yet made any profits at all because of heavy reinvestment needs. The new rules are comparable to the rules in other established stock markets in the world for their main boards. The changes have been necessary to enable capital markets to fund the new economy, because the main purpose of the equity market is not to enable investors to make a quick buck, but to be an avenue for channelling funds and resources as equity to invest in companies and enable companies to draw equity in order to be able to grow. So the changes have been necessary to enable the capital market to fund this new economy, particularly including companies in high-tech and knowledge-based industries. If we do not allow high-tech companies to list on the Stock Exchange, then either they will be choked off from equity capital and we will miss out on their growth, or they will list overseas, for example, on NASDAQ, and our stock market will wither. So we are in this business. This is again for professionals.

Column: 930



    At the same time, we have changed the regulatory philosophy - from a merit-based one, what Dr Wang called Koh Beng Seng's approach, although it was not just Mr Koh Beng Seng, it was the Government's approach, or what the Business Times called "the Confucian approach", to a disclosure-based one. Previously, we would assess the merits of a proposal and decide whether it is a good or a bad company. Now, we have basic criteria and as long as there is full disclosure and all the facts are put up, we allow the company to be listed and allow investors to go in. This has been necessary because finally, investors have to make their own decisions and to take responsibility for them. No merit-based regulator can guarantee that only successful companies will be listed and that investors will definitely make a profit.

    We changed the listing rules last September. Since then, five companies have been listed under the new rules which would not have qualified under the old rules. Only two are dot.com companies, as Dr Wang pointed out, MediaRing and Horizon.com. The other three are China Toll Bridges & Roads Ltd, ST Assembly Test Services Ltd and Chartered Semiconductor Manufacturing Ltd, of which STATS and CSM are also listed on NASDAQ and are by no means start-up companies.

    Our changes coincided with the great effervescence in the technology sector and tech stocks in the US markets. There is a new frontier, there is a gold rush mentality. Some people have made it big, others hope to make it even bigger. They are going in, they are trying as if the last train is about to leave the station. Not all will succeed - many will certainly fail. The excitement is for real reasons because the Internet is a dramatic breakthrough in technology which is going to change the lives of billions of people. But, of course, in all this excitement, we start with a good thing and get carried away by its momentum. There is the psychology of a speculative bubble, particularly in the US, in tech stocks. And this has buoyed other markets in the world, including Hong Kong, Bombay, KL and to a lesser extent

Column: 931

Singapore. At some point, the American market will come back to earth, the law of gravity will reassert itself and which will affect markets everywhere else. How or when, nobody can tell. If Dr Wang could be quite confident that this is going to happen within this year, contrary to what many other people expect, he could become very rich by shorting the market. On the other hand, if he misjudges, he might not be rich at all.

    So I cannot comment whether the Singapore market is too high or too low, much less on the merits of individual stocks or companies which are listed on the Stock Exchange. But I can tell you that not every company that calls itself dot.com is naturally and automatically an Internet company or destined for fabulous success. Investors have to decide whether to buy the shares in these companies, or in any other companies. You have got to know the risks. You have got to be prepared for the downside. And you have got to judge what your risk appetite is. If you are an investment fund, picking winners for your portfolio, with many potential winners in a big portfolio, that is fine. One goes sour, another one will turn out right. But if you are a widow investing your last CPF dollar, and you put it on a single company in the hope that you will get rich, then maybe you are better off keeping that money in a fixed deposit in a bank instead.

    I think overall, our new rules and philosophy are correct. The Government cannot stop companies from being listed on SGX because we think that their business is too risky, or because we think their shares are priced too high. Risk taking is the essence of business and particularly in the new economy. But we will educate the public on the risks so that people know what they are doing and go in with their eyes open. Whether they are actually looking or not, that is another matter. But we will not spare any effort to explain and to point out, and speeches by Dr Wang, MPs and other leaders will also be helpful.

    Of course, even with tight rules, as in the past, you must remember that

Column: 932

companies are not guaranteed to succeed. Whatever our rules, they can fail either for business reasons or because of fraud or crime, as Pan-El failed and Amcol ran into trouble. And even if a company is sound, its share price can still be inflated and not justified by the company's earnings and prospects. And indeed, Microsoft itself, which is undoubtedly a very good company with its share price at about $100, that is about 70 or 80 times its price earnings ratio. And Steve Balmer himself, who is now the CEO, had said, "My price is inflated, over-valued." As a result of which, it came down three or four dollars, but it is still over-valued. So I do not think it is possible for the Government to make sure that the Stock Exchange is a safe place.

    Anyway it is difficult to prevent people from taking risks, by keeping what we think are risky companies off the Stock Exchange. People who want risky investments find many ways to make them. They can invest overseas. In the old days, when the Malaysian stocks were listed on CLOB, they invested on CLOB, which is a different environment from the Singapore stock market. Or sometimes, if they cannot invest on the stock market, they put money on horses or many other things, or football, or even watch two raindrops on the windscreen and see which goes faster. That is their instinct. Our job is to encourage a more professional and sophisticated share market, not controlled by people looking at the screen through the window and hoping to guess the next move that the share price will make, but people who analyse the fundamentals, understand the business, know the way the industry is going and put bets in for the long term. So if you do not know about stocks, do not buy and sell based on the latest rumour or rely on hot tips from friends. Better entrust your money to a reliable fund manager, buy a unit trust, or leave your money in the bank. It is not as exciting, but it is much safer. Not totally risk-free, but much safer.

    What the Government can do is to enforce the rules of the market - have proper disclosure, have tight market surveillance, have quick action against

Column: 933

any price manipulation, any monkey business means severe penalties for offenders. Recently, we changed the law to introduce a new civil penalty for insider trading, to make it easier to punish or to obtain compensation from those who make improper use of insider information to trade and benefit themselves at the expense of others.

    Investors cannot just invest in a company based on the name of that company. They have to know what the company's business is, how the company is doing, what its prospects are, how much the company is realistically worth. For IPOs and share issues, all this information should be in the company prospectus. We will change our requirements for prospectuses to ensure that they contain all that investors reasonably expect to find it. And this will include information which is known to the directors of the corporation, or known to the persons performing a professional or advisory function in relation to the issue or proposed issue of securities.

    This is a move away from a "one-size-fits-all" prospectus. We will accommodate the greater diversity of companies being listed on SGX, and create an environment for intermediaries, like stockbrokers, investment bankers, accountants, even lawyers, are expected to play their part in ensuring that proper disclosure is made. But of course, while we can print a good prospectus, this will only help if people actually read the prospectuses, and do not just blindly subscribe to IPO shares confident that they will make a profit on the first day. And in fact, it is known in

Column: 934

some markets, you go to the stockbroker's office, you get the application form with the prospectus, you go out, you throw away the prospectus in the dustbin and you just take the form and hope that the shares are worth some money. Sometimes, even the form is worth some money. But that is not the way.

    I have explained the Government's approach towards liberalising and regulating the stock market, and set out what the Government can and cannot do. It is in the nature of stock markets and human psychology that the markets will go up and go down through cycles. These cycles are linked to the real economy, but often overshoot. They last seven years, 10 years, sometimes, like now in America, a bit longer. My suspicion is they are driven by young people who are seeing the cycle for the first time. They have never lost before, they have never seen the blood on the ground. It is exciting and exhilarating. It is their last chance to get in. They ramp it up. And then something goes wrong, it comes down again. And they have learned their lesson. But in 10 years' time, a new generation of greenhorns is born. So we should know this. We have been through this before. The stock market will not always go up. Sometimes, it will come down. So Singaporeans who want to invest on the stock market should know this and invest prudently.

    The Penal Code has made it clear that nothing is an offence which is done by a child under 7 years of age, or committed by a child aged between 7 and 12 years who has not attained sufficient maturity of understanding to judge the nature and consequences of his/her conduct on that occasion.

    This minimum age of 7 years is inherited from the common law of England. This minimum age provides a safety net for young offenders and protects them from exploitation of unscrupulous adults who may want to make use of children to carry out illegal activities. It also allows for early intervention by social and other authorities before a child progresses into a hardened offender.

    Although the minimum age of culpability is 7 years old, children are not subject to the same justice system as adults. The juvenile justice system adopts a restorative model that

In addition, there is an inherent safeguard as children between the ages of 7 and 12 years who do not have adequate understanding of the crimes they have committed will not be held criminally responsible.     The revisions made to the Education Scheme of Service since 1st January 2000 was not a general salary revision. Instead, new intermediate salary grades were added to the scheme of service. These changes were part of civil service-wide changes to the structure of Division 1 services. New salary grades were introduced for both the General Education Officer (GEO) and the Senior Education Officer (SEO) salary schemes. Previously, classroom teachers were only eligible for one promotion to the career grade of GEO 1A and GEO 2A. With the new intermediate GEO salary grade, they now have an additional promotion opportunity, ie, 2 promotions, before they reach the career classroom teacher grade.     The Ministry agrees that we need to provide an overall conducive environment to help attract and retain teachers. It is not salaries and promotions alone that determine retention ability. We have also implemented various schemes such as the Study Leave Scheme and the Professional Development Leave Scheme to enable officers to upgrade themselves academically through full-time graduate and postgraduate programmes.
